hints_html:
Again, this is not a derivative we immediately know so we have to use our toolbox of rules. Here, we have a composition of function so we use the chain rule, which states:

If \(h(x) = f(g(x))\) for differentiable f and g, then

\(\displaystyle h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)\)

The derivative of \(\displaystyle \sin^{-1}(x) = \arcsin(x)\) is

\(\frac{d}{dx}(\arcsin(x)) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}\)
hints_latex:

the chain rule, which states:

If $h(x) = f(g(x))$ for differentiable \emph{f} and \emph{g}, then

$\displaystyle h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)$
hints_raw:
Again, this is not a derivative we immediately know so we have to use our toolbox of rules. Here, we have a composition of function so we use the chain rule, which states:

If <math> h(x) = f(g(x)) </math> for differentiable ''f'' and ''g'', then 

<math> \displaystyle
h'(x) = f'(g(x))g'(x)
</math>
The derivative of <math> \displaystyle \sin^{-1}(x) = \arcsin(x) </math> is

<math>
\frac{d}{dx}(\arcsin(x)) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}
</math>
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
A quick application of the chain rule gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx}(\sin^{-1}(\sqrt{x})) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(\sqrt{x})^{2}}}\frac{d}{dx}(\sqrt{x})\\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x}}\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\\ &= \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x-x^{2}}}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Find the derivative of

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle\sin^{-1}(\sqrt{x})\end{aligned}\]

[Note:  Another notation for sin-1 is arcsin]
statement_raw:
{{Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH100/December 2010/Question 1/Statement/Header}}

Find the derivative of
:<math>\displaystyle\sin^{-1}(\sqrt{x})</math>
[''Note:''&nbsp; Another notation for sin<sup>-1</sup> is arcsin]
